newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - Pause in dlr/mark rally seen refreshing.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - Pause in dlr/mark rally seen refreshing.

text.p: A pause in the dollar's rally versus the mark will likely prove an opportunity for the U.S. currency to gather strength for fresh attacks on upside targets, chartists said.
After surging to 1.5590 marks on Monday in New York, the dollar hit a fresh 23-month high of 1.5735 marks overnight in Asia.

"We've extended yesterday's rally already," said Scott Siller, a senior technical analyst at MCM CurrencyWatch. "Usually when you get that second extension, you know it's time to cool off a little bit."
The dollar lost steam Tuesday in New York, slipping to 1.5575/85 marks at 1400 EST/1900 GMT from 1.5635/45 at the open.
The U.S. currency, nevertheless, is expected to battle its way higher again.
MMS International technical analyst Ken Boyer said he expects the dollar over the next few weeks to reach 1.5830 marks, a high from December 1994.
"We're definitely bullish and the target that is on the upside is 1.5830," Boyer said.
For his part, Siller contended the dollar could test in the next week or two 1.5950 to 1.60 marks, which he termed a 19-month bull channel projection area.
Yet he warned the dollar might get a "little toppy" and pull back after reaching that area.
The U.S. unit also retreated Tuesday after its latest trek higher versus the Japanese unit. It traded at 113.25/35 yen at 1400 EST/1900 GMT, down from 114.08/18 at the open.
Boyer of MMS pegged dollar support at 113 yen and predicted the dollar may retest its 1996 high at 114.92 yen in the next few days.
On Tuesday, the mark also weakened versus the Japanese currency, falling to about 72.60/70 yen in afternoon trade from 72.91/94 in early dealings.
Siller noted the weekly indicators show a lot of downside potential for mark/yen.

Siller sketched initial downside targets at 72.40 and 71.15 yen and warned that realizing these targets could mean a setback for dollar/yen also to 112.75 and 112.25, which he deemed respectively 50 percent and 62 percent retracements of the dollar move from 110.65 yen to 114.80.
